metadata.title: How to Profile your Dataset in 6 minutes or less | by Vincent Tatan | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to Profile your Dataset in 6 minutes or less
metadata.description: When I worked at Lazada (South East Asia E-Commerce), I was tasked to incentivize retailers with badges and rewards based on their performance. The impact is clear; by promoting high performing…

all_paragraphs: How could I profile my customers?
How do I determine characteristics of different employees?
When I worked at Lazada (South East Asia E-Commerce), I was tasked to incentivize retailers with badges and rewards based on their performance.

The impact is clear; by promoting high performing retailers, we promote quality products and deliveries to our users. This translates to long term benefits for Lazada: better user experience, better user loyalty and better sales revenue.
However, one question remains. How do we define “performance”? In other words, How do we define good and bad retailers?

Nike sells sports shoes with smaller product volumes but higher margins compared to Target with diverse product offerings. Specialized retailers (Nike) sell fewer product types than generalized retailers (Target).

If our baseline metrics are sales volume, could we say that Target is “better” than Nike? If no, then how do we define these groups of retailers so we can judge their performance to customize their rewards offerings?
Well, if you are confused as I am, you are right. Because there is no right or wrong answer. It depends on your domain expertise, intuition, and luck to determine the objective definition.
But there is a technique that you can execute quickly to shape your stories to tell.
“Everybody is a genius. But if you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life believing that it is stupid.” — Albert Einstein
Who are our consumers based on their purchases (market basket analysis)?
What kinds of retailers do we see in our dataset (clustering) ?
Profiling identifies natural groups and characteristics from observations in order to classify them into meaningful segments.
If executed well, you can suggest meaningful data profiles and persuade your stakeholders to take actions based on the profiles you generate.
To demonstrate how to do this, allow me to introduce K Means Clustering.
K Means clustering is an unsupervised ML method to determine natural groupings based on how each observation is laid out within multidimensional space.

By using Euclidean distance, k means clustering measures the straight line distance of points with their respective cluster seed (centroid). Then iterate them throughout different assigned groups until they converge.
It effectively clusters different customers/observations and features to create natural groupings.
Since I intend for this guide to be a short introduction for you to implement K Means Clustering, I include a StatQuest video which best explains its methodology.
Using K Means Clustering, I designed retailer categories such as specialized retailers, niche retailers, supermarket (daily products) and department store (wide product variety) retailers.
Then I used each category of retailer to evaluate different incentive plans and suggested personalized promotions and rewards for each seller.
This framework allowed me to promote the best sellers to Lazada users and improved long term sales and user experience by appx 34% from the baseline.
Since I could not share and publish Lazada data, let’s use the HR Retention dataset to get our hands dirty to profile with K Means Clustering.
What are the profiles of employees who are quitting the company. (Who’s Quitting Today?).
As a starting point, I started with 3 features:
Note that this is subjective. The idea here is to tell a story with the visualization shown by the data which anyone can interpret differently (hence unsupervised learning).

As a general starting point, I suggest to start simple and use 3 features of your pickings, then expand the n_input_features as necessary. A stretch goal you can aim is to use PCA or feature selection techniques to pinpoint features with maximum information gain to reach your goal.
Interestingly, Unsatisfied performer and Mediocre profiles quit the most while Underachievers and Satisfied Superstars are loyal to the company.
Once you are done with profiling, you can share your profiles and solutions such as the following:

The best thing about using clustering and data profiling is that you have a framework to base your story telling upon. Once you understand these structures, you will be able to form sensible hypotheses and solutions.
With that, congrats! You just did your first data science profiling with K Means Clustering within 5 minutes or less.
Disclaimer: There are more methods to improve such as choosing optimum n_clusters and feature selections with PCA or other methods. But this should get you started quickly and easily.
If you want to see more analysis on the HR Retention Data, please visit my article “Who’s Quitting”.
If you like this post, I have more toolboxes to boost your productivity.
As always, when in doubt, please reach out to me on Linkedin for any of your questions. I would be glad to answer your queries when time permits.
Thank you to Albert Bingei for revising this post.
I fight phishing with ML @ Google.

What I love about my job is that I use advanced ML algorithms and MLOps to protect Chrome, Gmail and Android users against phishing attacks which potentially steal life savings from vulnerable populations every week.
I am also a writer for Towards Data Science Medium to guide aspiring ML and data practitioners with 500k+ viewers globally.
